Archive for January, 2007

New Community College Legislation Introduced re: CalSTRS Law

Wednesday, January 10th, 2007

Just over ten percent of the newly introduced bills relate to education. Based on the initial percentage of education-related bills, it is likely that more than 200 bills impacting public education will be introduced during the 2007 legislative session. One of those bills, is relative to CalSTRS law as follows:
AB 36 (Niello): Public Employees’ Retirement: Fraud

“This bill would make it a crime for a person to make or present false material statements and representations in connection with those retirement systems’ benefits and applications, or to aid or abet someone in this regard. This bill would also make it a crime for a person to knowingly accept, with the intent to keep for personal benefit, a payment from any of those retirement systems with the knowledge that one was not entitled to the benefit. The bill would provide that a violation of these provisions is punishable by up to one year in a county jail, or a fine, or both, and restitution.”

Source: School Services California, Inc./Community College Update 12/15/06

Education Code Section 22461/CalSTRS

Saturday, January 6th, 2007

Education Code Section 22461 states in part:

“(a) Upon retaining the services of a retired member under Section….24214….the school district, community college district, county superintendent of schools, California State University, or other employing agency shall do both of the following regardless of whether the retired member performs the services as an employee of the employer, an employee of a third party, or an independent contractor.

(1) Advise the retired member of the earnings limitation set forth in Sections….24214….

(2) Maintain accurate records of the retired member’s earnings and report those earnings monthly to the system and the retired member regardless of the method of payment or the fund from which the payments were made.”

Blog: The law clearly states the process. In my opinion the college did not follow this process based upon information provided to me as a board member and to the public through news articles in 2006.

“Continuing inquiries is problematic to the board and could involve invasion of privacy.”? ? J. Tyler, MSJC VP Human Resources.

“Kadow said the college does not know exactly what Giese earns and if there are any doubts about retirement earnings, it should be between CalSTRS and Giese.”
G. Kadow, MSJC Board Chair.

Source: Press Enterprise 1-28-06 (Trustee presses hiring dispute)

“Her colleagues chastised her (Motte) Thursday for continually trying to bring up a matter they consider to be between Giese and CalSTRS, and not the college.”

Source: Press Enterprise 2-10-06 (Board renews contract over member’s protest)
